author: alexfig8
title: Interesting Minifig
review:
I bought this guy yesterday, on the day they came out, along with Taco Tuesday guy and the Getaway Glider.  It can be VERY easily felt for, as all you have to do is feel for 2 pairs of legs.  Here are my thoughts on it.

Box/Instructions

Same foil pack we get with the Collectable Minifigures, except this one is dark blue.  It features the Lego Movie logo in the corner and shows a sampling of the 16 minifigures in the series on the front.  It includes the standard mini-poster, which instead of showing how to build the minifigures, it advertises an app or something.

Parts

Other than the Hawaiian shirt torso, nothing too special here.  The bare legs can be useful for a swim suit, other than that nothing amazing.  The face is kinda fun though.

Minifigures

As well as some of the sets, my brother bought the Essential Guide to the Lego Movie.  From what I can understand by reading it, this guy appears on TV every night, looking for his pants, which he never finds.  We'll have to wait for the movie to see how this plays out in Lord Business' evil plot.

The build

Nothing new here.

The completed model

Looks decent, obviously a little hard to use in a city scene, but I'm sure people will come up with some creative uses for him.  Switch the bare legs for the white pants, and make him into just a citizen of your town, or put him at your pool MOC as a swimmer.  Overall, a decent minifig.

author: Odeinoichus
title: Honey, Where are my Pants?
review:
Set #71004 Where Are My Pants? Guy: Sharon's Co-Star from the brainwashing television series of the same name, I mean it has to be brainwashing citizens of Bricksberg because come on! But I digress, this minifigure is a brief cameo given physical form, as he didn't seem to do too much during the movie.

The most impressive aspect of this figure is his Hawaiian print shirt. Sadly it's only a single-sided torso print. He has a decent facial expression with a wide open smile and the 1950's Greaser Hairpiece first introduced with the Mechanic is back in black. His accessory is just a spare set of white LEGO legs, his pants if you will. Does this mean he's only wearing underwear?

Overall not much to say, but still nice to see in this series. If nothing else he comes with a useful Hawaiian print shirt for MOC fig fans.

author: sideswinger
title: Where is my BACK PRINTING?
review:
One of the most iconic and memorable aspects of The LEGO Movie has got to be the Where are my Pants? Guy. He delivered such memorable lines, such as, "Where are my paaaaaaaaants?," and, "Where are my paaaaaaants?" But my personal favourite line from this character was when he said, "Where are my paaaaaaaants?," which is the line this character is named after. He was released in 2014 to coincide with no other than The LEGO Movie, where he included 5 pieces, and retailed for $2.99.

On top is a hair-piece that's been around since 2012. It's great seeing it reused here, since it isn't the most common part out there. I've always loved the moulding surrounding it, and of course, it matches the on-screen appearance.

As for the head, it sports a very chipper smile that's super fitting for the character, and it's highly useful outside this series.

The torso, much like the face, is super useful outside this series, and the printing on that part is brilliant. I love the colourful flowers, like red, green, and orange, but his lack of back printing is unbelievably disappointing. Side arm printing would have been nice, but it's definitely more excusable than his blank back.

He does technically include two, but the set of legs attached to the figure depicting undergarments is the correct one to use. The use of a white waist piece combined with yellow legs definitely does a fantastic job depicting underwear, and it's such a simple yet effective technique.

Accessory-wise, he includes the best possible accessory ever, a pair of pants. It's just a white set of legs with no printing, but it is super effective, super fitting, and an absolute;y fantastic accessory that is an excellent inclusion with the character.

That's it for this figure, and overall, it is far from being the most detailed of the series, and it severely lacks back printing. With that being said, I feel like this series was practically made for this figure, as it's just an absolutely perfect inclusion, and it's one of the best figure choices in this entire set. Overall, I'm giving it a 4 out of 5, because while it isn't the most detailed, it's accurate, and iconic.
